content.webTitle: Tony Benn’s granddaughter delivers blow to Corbyn by calling for policy chief to go

fields.headline: Tony Benn’s granddaughter delivers blow to Corbyn by calling for policy chief to go
fields.bodyText: Emily Benn, the granddaughter of Tony Benn and a former parliamentary candidate, has asked the Labour party to consider expelling Jeremy Corbyn’s new head of policy, Andrew Fisher, for supporting the anarchist Class War party at the general election. As recriminations grow over Fisher’s appointment, Benn – who stood for Labour in Croydon South in May – has written to Labour’s general secretary, Iain McNicol, saying that Fisher’s previous behaviour “contradicts Labour party rules”, which state that supporting a non-Labour candidate will lead to automatic expulsion. Her dramatic intervention is a severe embarrassment to Corbyn, who was a close friend and political ally of the late Tony Benn. It reflects deep dismay across much of the party at the Labour leader’s choice of a hard-left and notoriously outspoken individual to fill such a key role in his inner circle. In the letter, sent on Friday and obtained by the Observer, Benn, who is also the niece of the shadow foreign secretary, Hilary Benn, cites a tweet that Fisher put out telling voters not to back her in Croydon South but to vote instead for the Class War candidate, Jon Bigger. The tweet from August last year, which has been deleted from Fisher’s account, said: “FFS if you live in Croydon South, vote with dignity, vote @campaignbeard.” @Campaignbeard was Bigger’s twitter account. Benn, who failed to take the safe Tory seat, says in the letter: “I was the parliamentary candidate for Croydon South, having been democratically elected by the local party. Actively advocating voting against the official Labour candidate, in favour of another party, contradicts Labour party rules.” Calling for Labour’s national executive committee (NEC) to investigate, she cites the party’s rule book, which says anyone who supports a candidate standing against the official Labour candidate “shall automatically be ineligible to be or remain a party member”. She adds: “The Labour party is a broad church. I welcome lively debate and robust challenge. However, as I’m sure you will agree, there is a clear difference between this and the behaviour of Mr Fisher referenced above.” Her move suggests the NEC could be heading for a tumultuous row over Fisher’s continued membership of the party. Many Labour MPs are complaining at what they see as attempts to pack the ruling body with Corbyn loyalists. Members of the parliamentary party were outraged at the appointment, and to a lesser extent the choice of leftwing Guardian columnist Seumas Milne as the new director of communications. The appointment of Fisher was raised by former minister Caroline Flint at Monday’s rowdy meeting of the parliamentary Labour party. On 8 May, the day after the general election, Fisher celebrated the defeat of Ed Balls, tweeting that it was “fitting that the architect of Labour’s miserable austerity-lite economic policies should lose #Balls”. In September 2014, he described the Labour party’s frontbench as “the most abject collection of complete shite”. On Friday Lord Grabiner became the second peer to abandon Labour’s benches in the House of Lords because of Corbyn’s leadership of the party, saying “I can’t square [staying] with my conscience”. He followed Lord Warner, who resigned the Labour whip five days earlier, saying Labour was no longer “a credible party of government-in-waiting”. Today Labour’s former policy chief, Jon Cruddas, writing in the Observer attempts to chart a way forward for Labour while criticising the way it has allowed the Tory chancellor of the exchequer, George Osborne, to claim the devolution agenda as his own. Cruddas, who announces the formation of a new grouping of MPs, party members and council leaders called Labour Together, says the party is “stuck in an unpopular, outdated politics of taxing and spending and using state control” which he says “has got us into a situation in which a Tory chancellor looks more in tune with our Labour councils in the north than the Labour party itself”. He applauds Corbyn for challenging the party to rethink “the way in which it does politics” but says it has to develop a policy agenda that appeals to a wide cross-section of voters, while at the same time reclaiming the devolution agenda as its own. Shadow energy secretary Lisa Nandy, the Labour MP for Croydon North Steve Reed, and council leaders Judith Blake (Leeds) and Nick Forbes (Newcastle) will join the group.
